THE SCHOONER ENDEAVOR. JOHN MORTON CLINCH, Administrator, v. THE UNITED STATES. NATHANIEL G. SIMONDS, Administrator, v. THE SAME. NATHAN MATTHEWS, Administrator, v. THE SAME. JAMES G. FREEMAN, Receiver, v. THE SAME. CHARLES T. LOVERING, Administrator, v. THE SAME. THOMAS N. PERKINS, Administrator, v. THE SAME. JAMES C. DAVIS, Administrator, v. THE SAME. CHARLES K. COBB, Administrator, v. THE SAME. DANIEL W. WALDRON, Administrator, v. THE SAME. WILLIAM G. PERRY, Administrator, v. THE SAME. FRANK DABNEY, Administrator, v. THE SAME. JOHN E. DEARBORN, Administrator, v. THE SAME. FRANCIS M. BOUTWELL, Administrator, v. THE SAME. GEORGE G. KING, Administrator, v. THE SAME.

[French spoliations

114, 1623, 1780, 3504, 3874, 4187, 5012, 1140. Decided February 1, 1909.] On the Proofs. The schooner Endeavor on her homeward voyage resists search, but is 'captured. While in possession of the prize crew she is recaptured by an English man-of-war and restored to the *243possession of lier first mate and tier American crew. But she is again captured by a French privateer. At the time of this second capture she does not resist search. Subsequently she is condemned by a French prize court. I.To justify reprisals some specific wrong must have been committed and the seizures must be by way of compensation, i. e., as a means of satisfaction without resort to actual war. II.While reprisals are acts of war in fact it is for the state affected by them to determine for itself whether the relation of actual war is intended. III. Neither France nor the United States treated the seizures by French privateers as reprisals. IV. American vessels were seized by French privateers both before and after the treaty with Great Britain of 1795 on the ground that they were violating the treaty of 1778 or some regulation of France. V.The United States abrogated the treaty of 1778 with France by the Act 7th July, 1798. (1 Stat. L., p. 5780). VI. The legislation of Congress in 1708 was intended' to meet and prevent by force the capture of American vesels by French L privateers and to that extent was retaliatory; but considered as reprisals it amounted to no more than was justified by the law of self-defense. VII. Although France was designated in this, legislation as an enemy the war thus carried on was limited, and for that reason the court has recognized the right of France as a belligerent to search American vessels as those of a neutral. VIII.It is settled by the decisions of the Supreme Court and of this court that the condition of affairs was that of limited war, ^ in its nature similar to a prolonged series of reprisals. But the United States did not elect to regard such seizures as acts of war. IX.In the consideration of the French spoliations this court has followed the executive and political departments of the Government in treating them as claims arising out of the acts of France in peace and not as claims originating in war. X.Where a vessel illegally resisted search and escaped she continued liable to condemnation if captured by another privateer on the same voyage. The cases reviewed. XI.The burden is upon the claimants to show that the master was not allowed to be present and defend in the prize court. Where the protest does not so allege and there is no proof to show that he was prevented it must be held that he might , have appeared. *244The Reporters’ statement of the case: The following are the facts of the case as found by the court: I. The schooner Endeavor, whereof Nathaniel Griffin was then master, being an armed vessel carrying a commission issued by the President of the United States under the act of July 9, 1798 (1 Stat. L., 578), sailed on a return commercial voyage from Demerara on the 11th day of October, 1799, bound to Boston, stopping en route at several of the West Indian islands. While peacefully pursuing said voyage, on the 6th day of November, 1799, she was seized by the French privateer Victor, Captain Mace, after resistance to visitation and search, and combat, and ordered to Porto Pico. The circumstances of said voyage, resistance, combat, and capture were testified to by the master' in his protest made at Portland, Me., November 23, 1799, as follows: That he sailed from Demerara on the eleventh day of October, bound to Boston, under convoy of the frigate Syren, Capt. M. Cooslin, in company with five other Americans; that they arrived at Martinico on the eighteenth of the same October, from whence they again sailed on the twenty-sixth of the same month, under the same convoy, for St. Kitts and Tortola, in company with about sixty sail of British and about thirty sail of American merchantmen; that on the second day of November following they took their departure from Tortola, and on the next day himself and about nineteen others parted from the convoy, and that nothing-material occurred until the sixth, when at eight o’clock a. m. he discovered three sail ahead of him standing to the southward, which proved to be the privateer La Victor, Capt. Mace, from Porto Pico, manned with about sixty negroes, mulattoes, English, and Americans. Among the latter .was a Bostonian by the name of Calob Thomas. The other two vessels were prizes. Immediately on his bearing down he hoisted French national colours and fired one of his bow chacers; he then gave three cheers and fired a second bow chace; that he, the deponent, then put himself in the best order of defence and commenced firing his stern chacer; that upon his firing the second gun the privateer struck *245national and hoisted the bloody flag, hoisted his square sail yard and manned it, in order for boarding, and fired a volley of musketry; that he then struck his colors, hoisted out his boat, and went on board the privateer with his papers. They then sent a prize master and crew on board the En-deavour, after which they ordered him to return on board his vessel for his clothes, his crew, and their clothes; that he was treated decently while on board the privateer, but very abusively while on board his own vessel, by the prize master, who struck him in the face with a spade and threatened to kill him if he did not go directly on board the privateer; that they robbed him of forty dollars in cash, his quadrant books, charts, books, glass, all his valuables, clothes to the amount of two hundred dollars; after which they went on board the privateer, ‘ the capt. of which ordered the En-deavour for Porto Pico, after returning the mate to her, who had been much abused and wounded. They then made sail to the southward, being in latitude 23 N., long. 65 51 W. The two prizes with the privateer proved to be the scho. Experiment, Capt. Wescott, for Boston from Martinico, and the schooner Betey, Capt. Pider, from Martinico for Plymouth, both captured that morning. The captain of the privateer finally gave up to them the schooner Experiment, before mentioned, to bring the officers and crews of the three Vessels to the United States, the Experiment having nothing on board but ballast. The mate in his protest on the island of St. Thomas, December 24,1799, after reciting the sailing of the vessel under ■convoy, its capture, the treatment and removal of the captain and his men, as recited in the protest of the master as aforesaid, says in substance that after leaving the privateer, and while on her way to Porto Pico, the Endeavor was retaken by an English frigate, whose commander, under a claim of salvage, took out part of her cargo at sea and gave up said vessel to her mate, together with two men to help navigate her to Boston. On November 15 the Endeavor was again taken by the French, who put on board five men and ordered her to Porto Pico, where she arrived on the 18th of said month, where the mate was imprisoned without money *246or friends. Botli said captures and the recapture were while the Endeavor was sailing on the same voyage. Subsequently the Endeavor and her cargo were condemned as good prize for the benefit of the owners and crew of the Alliance by decree of the tribunal of commerce and prizes sitting at Basse-Terre, in the island of Guadeloupe, January 7, 1800, and thereby became a total loss to the owners thereof. The decree of condemnation recites: “ The tribunal of commerce and of prizes established in the island of Guadeloupe, sitting at Basse-Terre, in said island, in its ordinary meeting of the 18th of Nivose, year 8, of the French Republic one and indivisible, considering the report of the seizure made on the high seas on the 25th of Brumaire last of the American ship Endeavour, from Boston, Nathaniel Griffin, master, by the privateer EAUaiance, Capt. Dupuy; the examination made oii Frimaire 2d last, on the occasion of said seizure, by Citizen Bébian, delegate in Porto Rico; the analysis of said vessel’s papers in English compared and signed Bébian, by Citizen Menard, assistant sworn interpreter of said language; all of which papers, as well as those which were analyzed, having been placed at the bar, said interpreter being present at the meeting. “ Having heard the president’s report and the argument of the commissioner of the executive directory, the case is deliberated upon: “ Whereas it appears from said analyzed papers, as well as from said reports, that the master of said vessel carried a commission of the President of the United States, which authorized him to run against and seize armed French vessels and to take them into American ports, which is evidently contrary to the duty of neutrality; “ Whereas there is no roll of the crew among said papers, but only a simple agreement between the captain and the men of his vessel, bearing no signature of public officers; “ Whereas the cargo of said vessel consists in sugar, rum, and coffee, taken on board at Demerary, a colony possessed by the English; “Applying Io article 12 of the regulations concerning seizures of October 21, 1744, which says: £ Will be declared good prize all foreign vessels, etc., * * * or which have not on board the list of the crew, as prescribed and issued by the public authorities of the neutral ports from which said vessels have sailed;’ “ 2° article 4 of the decree of the executive directory of Ventóse 12, year 5, which says: ‘ In conformity with the law *247of February 14, 1793, tbe dispositions of the regulations of October 21, 1744, and of July 26, 1778, concerning the manner to ascertain the ownership of neutral vessels and cargoes shall be carried out according to their form and tenor; “ ‘ Therefore will be declared good prize every American vessel which has not on board a list of the crew in due form as prescribed by the model attached to the treaty of February 6, 1778, the application of which is ordered by articles 25 and 27 of said treaty.’ “ 3° article 1st of the law of Nivose 29, year 6, which says: ‘ The condition of vessels with regard to their quality as neutral or as enemy shall be determined by their cargo; therefore every vessel found on the high seas and loaded in part or .totally with merchandise of English origin or from her colonies shall be declared good prize, whoever may be the owner of these goods or merchandise.’ “ The tribunal giving judgment in favor of the request of the commissioner of tlie executive directory declares as good prize the American ship Endeavour, her tackle, appurtenances, and cargo, and orders their sale in the accustomed manner to the benefit of captors, owners, and interested parties of the privateer I?Alliance, an inventory of everything having been made beforehand in presence of all those concerned.” II. The Endeavor was a duly registered vessel of the United States, owned solely by Daniel Sargent, a citizen of the United States, residing in Boston; of 83|| tons burthen; built in Massachusetts in the year 1795; and registered at the port of Boston and Charlestown. III. The cargo of the Endeavor consisted of sugar, coffee, and rum, and was owned solely by the said Daniel Sargent, with the exception of an adventure of sugar and coffee, the property of Nathaniel Griffin, master of the vessel, and a citizen of the United States. IY. Said claims were not embraced in the convention between the United States and the Republic of France, concluded on the 30th of April, 1803. They were not claims growing out of the acts of France, allowed and paid in whole or in part under the provisions of the treaty between the United States and Spain, concluded on the 22nd of February, 1819, and were not allowed, in whole or in part, under the provisions of the treaty between the United States and France of the 4th of July, 1831. *248Mr. Brooks Adams for the claimants: I. The issue presented by the facts proved in this cause may be thus stated: Did resistance to search by an American merchantman, between.the years 1796 and 1800, by an armed vessel flying the French flag, raise a conclusive presumption of her guilt as a carrier of contraband of war for Great Britain, then the enemy of France? This question can only be resolved by first determining whether during that period France, when seizing American ships, was exercising in good faith her right as a belligerent to suppress illicit commerce by a neutral or whether she was seeking to indemnify herself for an'alleged breach of faith by America toward France. And here arises at the threshold the fundamental error of law contained, either expressly or by implication, in the theory of the Government in this class of causes — that nations must either be at war or at peace; that if France was not at war with the United States she must have been at peace, and if at peace, that she must have been acting as a belligerent in the exercise of the right of search in the period from 1796 to 1800. Nations are not necessarily either at war or else at peace. There is a well-established intermediate condition known as “ reprisals.” A condition of “ reprisals ” exists when a nation, conceiving itself to be wronged, resorts to violence to right its wrong. That violence may lead to retaliation, and retaliation may lead to war. In this event the courts.hold that the warlike animus existed from the outset and that ships captured before the declaration of war are good prize. But, on the other hand, a reconciliation may be effected, and then the peaceful animus is held to relate back, and compensation will be made on both sides for losses. This is the doctrine laid down by Lord Stowell and expounded by Wheaton. (The Boedes Lust, 5 C. Robinson, 233; Elements of International Law, Wheaton, pp. 290, 291.) Until recently a condition of reprisals usually preceded all great wars. It preceded the Seven Years’ war, the war between England and Spain of 1739, and such a condition existed between the United States and Spain during Mr. Monroe’s administration, when General Jackson invaded Florida, occupied St. Marks, and executed Arbuthnot and *249Ambrister. Yet the-two countries remained at peace, and the controversy was ended by the dispatch of John Quincy Adams to Irving, the United States envoy at Madrid, in which he laid down the true doctrine of reprisals. (Foreign Relations, 4, 544.) In 1796 a condition of reprisals existed between France and the United States which was terminated by the treaty of 1800. These reprisals arose in the following manner: In 1776 the American colonies declared their independence of Great Britain, and war ensued. In 1778, during this war, France made a treaty of alliance with the colonies. By Article XI of that treaty the United States guaranteed to France her possessions in America. By a treaty of commerce made contemporaneously, Article XVII, the United States agreed to open her ports to French ships of war, with their prizes, closing them to the enemies of France, and by Article XXII of the same treaty it was mutually agreed that in case of war privateers hostile to either nation should be excluded from the ports of the other, save in so far as they might be permitted to buy food to carry them home. In 1783 Great Britain acknowledged the independence of America, and in the treaty of peace conceded to the United States her northern boundary upon the Lakes, substantially as it now exists. So keen was Washington’s anxiety to secure the boundary of the Great Lakes, because such a frontier would be defensible, that, a month before the signing of the definitive treaty, he sent General Steuben to arrange with General Haldimand for the cession of Mackinac, Detroit, Fort Erie, Niagara, Oswego, together with Point Au-fer and Dutchmans Point, Lake Champlain. Haldimand then declined to execute the treaty, and the English thereafter continued so to decline, probably, as Washington always suspected, intending to hold these points as a base from which to invade the United States in the future. (Foreign Relations, 1, 225; Washington to Lafayette; Writings of Washington, Ford, XI, 28, 29.) The possession of these posts by England put the United States in an untenable position in the case of war by exposing her flank and rear. This was proved subsequently, during the war of 1812, when Wellington advised his Gov-*250eminent that no invasion of the United States from Canada was practicable without command of the Lakes. (Wellington’s Supplementary Dispatches, 1, 426.) It is also certain that Washington anticipated an attack by England by way of the Lakes as early as 1790 and looked forward to such an attack with apprehension because of England’s command of the Lakes. (Works of John Adams, VIII, 497.) In 1793 war broke out between England and France, and the English determined to starve the French by cutting off supplies from beyond the sea. The most important colonial supplies reached France from. Santo Domingo during the war in American ships. These ships, by orders in council of November 26, 1793, Great Britain caused to be seized by her navy and condemned by her prize courts. The act of seizure amounted to piracy. Washington in retaliation proclaimed an embargo. Thus in the autumn of 1793 England and the United States were in a condition of reprisals, and Washington had to choose between turning those reprisals into war by executing the treaties with France, or obtaining a cession of the northwestern posts, which would make the United States defensible, and also obtaining compensation for the losses which the Union had sustained by abandoning France. He. chose to abandon France by the negotiation of Jay’s treaty in 1795. Thereupon the French withdrew their minister and announced that they should treat American vessels as the Americans permitted the English to treat them, which, in French diplomatic language, meant to seize them, or in other words, to begin reprisals. (Foreign Delations, 1, 579, 582, 583.) In insisting on indemnity this court has held that France was justified, for thereby France lost West Indian possessions which the United States was bound to defend. {Gray v. United States, 21 Ct. Cls., 378.) To indemnify herself France pushed reprisals as far as she could without forcing the United States to war. An enormous mass of evidence exists to prove this proposition. One reference, however, will suffice. (Deport of the Secretary of State, Foreign Delations, 2, 232, 234.) *251In order to avert war the United States sent two special missions to France. Had both these missions failed, and had war supervened, these claimants would have had no standing in this court. But war did not supervene. The United States purchased peace and release from her treaties of alliance and commerce by sacrificing to France the plunder of the period of reprisals. The United States might have effected the same object by paying France an indemnity for breach of her treaty obligations and by raising the money for the indemnity by an ordinary loan. She preferred to make a forced loan, and consequently she became liable to her citizens, who thus became her involuntary creditors, precisely as she would have been liable to voluntary creditors. 0Gray v. United States, 21 Ct. Cls., 378.) The difference to the claimants has, however, been considerable. In the one case the United States would have paid, her obligation honestly, while in the other she has refused payment of the principal for one hundred and six years, and has altogether repudiated the interest. The first mission to France failed because of the greed of Tallyrand. Tallyrand demanded a. fee of £55,000 for his own services, and a subscription of £1,333,000 to a Dutch loan. These terms being rejected he tried intimidation by sending Messrs. Pinckney and Marshall home. (Foreign Relations, 2, 164, 166, 168, 191.) When the news of the insult reached America, Congress passed two acts authorizing American ships to arm (Stat. L., 1, 561, 572), and the President announced to Congress that he would never send another minister to France without the assurance that such an envoy should be respected. (Foreign Relations, 2, 199.) Immediately upon hearing of this ultimatum Tallyrand gave the required assurance (Foreign Relations, 2, 242), the second mission was sent, and that mission negotiated the treaty of 1800. The French conceded a reasonable adjustment only because the United States had, after the armament of her merchantmen, proved herself to be formidable at sea. She swept the French pivateers from the ocean. In six months the *252rates of insurance fell nearly one half. (Report of the Committee of the House of Representatives, Naval Affairs, 1, 69.) With such an enemy France could not afford to make war. In the negotiations which led to the treaty of 1800, the French presented and adhered to this alternative: The United States must pay damages or perform her duty. “ Either the ancient treaties, carrying with them the privileges resulting from anteriority, together with the stipulations for reciprocal indemnity, or a new treaty promising equality, unattended with indemnities.” (Foreign Relations, 2, 332.) The United States chose the second alternative, freedom without indemnity, and thereupon became responsible to her injured citizens for the indemnity which she might have exacted from France — for France and the United States having amicably adjusted their differences, the peaceful animus related back. War had never existed. (Boecles Lust, 5 C. Robinson, 233; Gray v. United States, 21 Ct. Cls.; see the whole opinion of Mr. Justice Davis.) The issue of this cause is therefore clear. The controversy between France and America did not relate to the right of search, except collaterally. The dispute hinged upon the repudiation of treaties. America declined to perform her treaty obligations and thereby seriously injured France. France undertook to indemnify herself by reprisals. The alternative presented was war or compensation for mutual losses. The parties chose peace, and then adjusted the terms of settlement. Had America elected to pay France an indemnity for the breach of her treaties, as Tallyrand suggested, France, on her side, would have been obliged to pay for the ships she had seized, as England paid under Jay’s treaty. A tribunal would have passed upon all captures, and in each American case the burden would have rested on France to prove that the ship captured had been rightly condemned because she was a smuggler loaded with contraband of war. Mere evidence of resistance to search would have been immaterial, for the very existence of the international tribunal implied that conditions existed beyond the ordinary jurisdiction of prize courts. Those conditions were “reprisals; ” and during “ reprisals ” the duty of the mariner is to resist the enemy of his country; not to submit to *253capture. The United States, having no navy, called upon her loyal seamen to defend themselves. They did defend themselves, and by so doing averted a general war by making the prospect of war distasteful to France. The Endeavor stood upon precisely the basis on which a national ship lost in action would have stood, and such losses are usually made good upon the peaceful termination reprisals. In this instance, when the commissioners were seeking a basis for mutual compensation, both sides proposed to provide for payment for national ships destroyed in action.a (Foreign Eelations, 2, 320, 333, 338.) Public ships taken on either side shall be restored or paid for. (Foreign Eelations, 2, 334.) II. I apprehend that upon no principle of international law, regard being had to the evidence, can resistance to boarding by the French by American seamen between, the years 1796 and 1800 be held to be even prima facie evidence of illicit commerce, and therefore, standing by itself, that it can not be held to have been ground for condemnation in such a case as the Endeavor. At most it could only be adduced in support of other evidence pointing to trade in contraband. In this case there is no such evidence. • But so strong is this case that even setting aside, for the sake of argument, the evidence touching the condition of reprisals which then existed between America and France, and basing this defense only on the abuse by France of her belligerent rights at sea, the admitted piracy of the French in the West Indies not only justified self defense, but made it imperative that American merchantmen should defend themselves. No error can be grosser than to assume that the right of search is an arbitrary power. On the contrary, it is a police power resembling the execution of civil process, and limited like the execution of civil process. This principle is established beyond dispute. It was laid down by Lord Stowell, among other jurists, in the Maria (1C. Eobinson, 340), Lord Stowell’s leading decision on the lawfulness of resistance. *254A neutral ship may be convicted of smuggling contraband, as any other smuggler may be convicted, upon various kinds of evidence, and one kind of such evidence is resistance to search, because resistance raises a presumption that the resisting ship contained something she wished to conceal; but this presumption may be rebutted, and it may be rebutted by evidence tending to show that the right of search was exercised oppressively or violently. During this period the French not only admitted piracy but that their colonial governments lived on piracy. Among such admissions, in the preamble to a decree issued July 31, 1798, the Directory declared that “ Considering that foreigners and pirates have abused the latitude allowed * * * in the West Indies * * * in order to cover with the French flag their extortions, and the violation of the respect due to the law of nations, and to the persons and property of allies- and neutrals,” it is decreed, etc. (Foreign Relations, 2, 222, 223.) The cruiser who attacked the Endeavor admitted piracy, or at least the intent to commit violence. She flew the piratical flag, and no merchantman permits boarding by a pirate. (See for further evidence of French piracy, His-toire de la Gaudeloupe, Lacour, 2, 418, et seq.; Report o’f Timothy Pickering, Secretary of State, to John Adams, President of the United States, Jan. 21, 1799. Foreign Relations, 2, 232.) In an international controversy such as this, the rights of parties should not be regulated by municipal but by Roman law, and under the Roman law controversy on this issue would be impossible. If Lord Stowell was correct in holding that the right of search resembled civil process, as he certainly was, then the Endeavor was justified in resisting any vessel flying the piratical flag, or threatening violence, and all French privateers then in the West Indies threatened violence. Any Roman citizen might resist an officer who transcended or abused his authority. But in this cause the defense may set aside the Roman law and rest on municipal law. Any American citizen may resist even an officer of justice bearing the warrant of a court having jurisdiction, if the *255officer enter wrongfully, though believing that he enter rightfully. (Commonwealth, v. Newton, 123 Mass., 420.) So the citizen may resist where an arrest is attempted in so menacing a manner as to threaten bodily harm. (Jones v. Temas, App., 12; State v. Muncly, 2 Marvel (Del.), 433.) The Kentucky Court, of Appeals has laid down the law thus: He is justified in resisting arrest who “ has reasonable grounds to believe and does believe * '* * that by submitting to arrest * * * he will * * * be in danger of great bodily harm or of losing his life.” (Fleetwood v. The Commonwealth of Kentucky, 80 Kentucky, 5; West v. Cabell, 153 U. S., 86.) If the Kentucky judiciary had had in mind the case of the Endeavor, it could have used no more apposite .words than these. Mr. Wm. T. S. Curtis for the claimants. Mr. Theodore J. Pickett was on the brief: We contend that under the facts as found and as admitted by counsel for the defendant, if this court is to follow its former decisions and those of other courts, a reversal should be had and an award made in .favor of claimants on the ground that the capture was illegal. The evidence shows beyond all question that the initial act of the captor Victor was unlawful, and thus gave cause for our captain to defend himself as best he could. The raising of the bloody flag, an emblem of piracy, followed by the firing of a volley of musketry from a large crew of blacks, gave to our master reason for believing that he was to deal with a pirate, whose captives received as a reward nothing less than death, and, under these circumstances, had he not endeavored in some measure to defend himself and his vessel he would have been branded in the eyes of all mankind as either a coward or a fool. The visitation by the captor was not exercised in a lawful manner and no resistance on our part was shown until the captor, by his actions, had led us to believe he was piratical. Had the visitation been lawfully exercised, then our resistance, under former rulings of this court, might have de*256barred us from recovery, but not when the captor unlawfully attacked us. In the case of the ship Rose (36 C. Cls. B., 291) the court says: “ Forcible resistance is good cause for condemnation, except in cases where a neutral is justified in defending against extreme violence threatened by a cruiser grossly abusing his commission.” (See case of Maria, 1 C., Bob., 340, cited in 36 C. Cls. B., 303.) The case of the Jane, Sorenson (37 C. Cls. B., 24), is not adverse to the position we now take, for there the court held in substance that the resistance, in order to bar the claimant,' must have been against a lawful cruiser acting in a lawful manner in making the visitation and search, and the record herein shows that the acts of the privateer were unlawful and in abuse of her commission and her obligations to neutrals on the high seas. The unwarranted attack, the firing twice of his bow chasers, the firing of a volley of musketry, with the bloody flag at her masthead, surely can not be contended as the legal and proper exercise of the right of visitation such as is required by the rules of the sea and the principles of international law. Upon this same subject Halleck, on page 610 of his able work on international law, says: “ But although it is the duty of the neutral to submit to the lawful search of the belligerent, and to all acts that are necessary to accomplish that object, it by no means follows that the belligerent is subject to no restraint in the exercise of his .right. It is not sufficient that the right is lawful; it must be exercised in a lawful manner * * The fact that the privateer hauled down the French flag and continued her attack under the bloody flag would be sufficient, even under the then laws of France, to make her-action unlawful, and if so then it can not be successfully contended that we resisted a lawful visitation. In the case of the brig Union (Lunt, No. 974) will be found printed a decree of the council of prizes signed by the great French jurist, Portalis. The decree recites that the French privateer making the attack deceptively hoisted *257an English flag (in our case a bloody flag, even worse), and the council of prizes said: “ Now, by the laws, this act of perfidy suffices to cause the adjudication of damages, because we read in the ordinance of 17 March, 1696, that such a procedure is contrary to the public faith, to the honor of the French flag, to the ordinances, particularly to that of 1681. Consequently, the legislature directs that all captains of its vessels or those armed as cruisers by its subjects shall be required to hoist the French flag before firing the summoning gun; makes to them very express inhibition and prohibitions to fire under a foreign flag under penalty, &q., &c.” The council released the Union and directed the owners ■ of the privateer to pay all damages, &c. We submit that ■ had Portalis ever sat in judgment on this seizure by the Victor he would have held that she had violated the French laws and her commission and was liable for all damages growing out of her illegal acts. The fact that when we were subsequently captured by the French privateer Alliance, Captain Dupuy, we peacefully submitted to the visitation and search, because the act of that privateer was lawfully exercised, shows that it was not the purpose of Captain Griffin to unlawfully resist a lawful visitation. ITad the privateer Victor not violated her commission, as .well as her duties upon the high seas to a neutral vessel, Captain Griffin would have submitted to her, but the bloody flag and a volley of musketry following-two discharges of the bow chasers can not be classified as a very friendly act or one which the defendants can now present against us as a lawful exercise of the belligerent right, especially when the French laws made such action illegal. The resistance cases heretofore decided by' this court against the claimants will be found to disclose that the resistance followed the lawful visitation of the captors; and we submit neither this court nor any other has ever held that resistance following an unlawful visitation will exonerate the captor from liability for his acts. In the case of the ship Aurora, Sutor, heretofore decided, it appears an engagement or combat lasting one hour took place, but the facts showing who was the aggressor did not appear. This court there held.: *258“ The facts and circumstances attending and leading to the engagement between the two vessels not having been shown by either party, and not being set forth in the protest of the master of the'Aurora, made shortly after the capture of the vessel, it cannot be held she was without fault or that her seizure and condemnation were illegal.” Had we been able to show that the captor in that case violated her commission or the rules of international law, as we have done in the case at bar, the court would have held, from what it concludes, that the capture was illegal, and recovery would have been had. In the Aurora the record is silent as to details of the attack and fight, but in the case of the Endeavor the conduct of the captor was illegal and unlawful, and as held in the above-cited cases any defense on our part would be justified. There is and can be no similarity between this and the cases of the Jane and the Bose; for in the last-mentioned cases the captor’s action and the search were lawful and lawfully made, and consequently resistance was unlawful, but in the case at bar the initial act of the captor was unlawful, and the defendant is thus estopped from pleading in bar that we resisted. When captured by the privateer Alliance, nineteen days after the first capture, not an action or word on our part could be construed as resistance or the impairment of the right of visitation, or of the right of adjudication of the prize; in other words, we were not in delicto. As above argued, no act of ours as against the privateer Victor could be construed as violative of our duties as a neutral, but admitting for argument’s sake merely that the acts of the first privateer Victor were legal, yet when we were captured by the Alliance we were offering no resistance to the belligerant right of visitation. Sailing under belligerent convoy would be constructively resistance if captured in delicto, and would not be considered as a taint longer than the association of convoy actually existed. (See case of Galen, Mackey, 37 C. Cls. R., 95.) Like in the case of convoy, the resistance, even if unlawful, would not extend so as to justify our subsequent capture by the Alliance, when it is admitted the Endeavor showed no resistance. *259In the case of the Dolphin, Buntin, cited by Mr. Trainer, the act of visitation by the privateer was lawfully exercised, and consequently the court held the resistance to be unlawful. In the present case the reverse is the fact, as the Victor’s every act was illegal, and our resistance was in opposition to an unlawful act of the captor. Mr. John W. It has been settled by this court that resistance to France’s belligerent right of visitation and search justified capture and condemnation. {Bose, Chase, 36 C. Cls. K., 290; Jane, Sorenson, 37 C. R., 99.) Sir William Scott was of the opinion that the mere act of carrying instructions or a commission to resist lawful visitation was sufficient to complete an act of hostility. {The Maria, 1 C. B., 198; Fame, 36 C. Cls. B., 361; Hiram, 41 C. Cls. B.-, 12.) French, was rescued from the prize crew by her master, then taken by an English vessel, and finally retaken by a French vessel, sent in and condemned, the court has held the rescue by the master to have furnished a valid ground of condemnation, although the condemnation made upon the second capture did not recite the rescue from the first captor. {Dolphin, Buntin, H. Roy den, 37 Law Journal Common Pleas, 66; Law Reports Common Pleas, 47; 17 Law Journal Reports, New Series, 214; 16 Weekly Reporter, 205; The George, 1 Sumner R., 151; Parmeter v. Claimants can not condone their own wrong in resisting visitation and search upon the first capture and attempt to estop the Government’s defense by alleging misconduct of the second captor, especially where their own wrong wholly *263changed the relation of their vessel toward the French nation. They must present themselves here as innocent neutrals and not as those who abandoned their neutrality and submitted their case to the arbitrament of war.
